>I said that *if* your solution *required* recurrent connections,  
>*and* you were indeed fully evaluating the networks (as in a sorted  
>node, single update), that NEAT would not converge.

Ah, I see. Sorry about the confusion!

>...as networks  
>increase in size, they can easily outgrow the fixed iteration count,  
>such that inputs may not make it all the way through the network.   
>This, in turn, creates a time delay or memory.

Indeed. The unusual thing about the delay lines is the way they seem 
to function purely as a delay, with only one input and one output, 
rather than also performing some other processing along the way.

One could say, of course, that the inherent feedback in evaluating a 
network multiple times like this does imply a kind of recurrence 
anyway, as the network's output on any given timestep naturally 
affects its input on the next.

--Darren
